Award.AwardTitle: Cationic Cobaltocenium Polyelectrolyte Polymers: Synthesis, Self-Assembly and Utilities
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Chuanbing Tang of the University of South Carolina will explore the synthesis and properties of cobaltocenium-containing polymers, the isoelectronic analogues of the more widely studied ferrocene-containing macromolecules. The approach is to synthesize and characterize cobaltocenium-containing polymers by controlled polymerization of cobaltocenium-containing monomers and by post-polymerization modification routes; to study the assembly of cobaltocenium-containing block copolymers and explore the template synthesis of cobalt oxide nanoparticles; and to perform preliminary studies into the use of the cobaltoceneum-containing polymers in battery electrodes The broader impacts involve training undergraduate and graduate students in research, broadly disseminating research results through publications and presentations at conferences, as well as participating in integrated educational activities for high school, undergraduate and graduate students to stimulate their interest in science and technology with enhanced global research and education training opportunities.

Plastics are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. This research will explore new approaches to include metal atoms within the polymer structure, which can impact the polymer's electrical properties and potentially lead to materials for light-weight, flexible electrochemical batteries. The metal-containing polymers could also be used to template the creation of technologically important magnetic or catalytic nanoparticles (small pieces of material with dimensions on the order of 1 to 100 nanometers, which is about 10,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

we have achieved and discovered the following during the three-year period: (1) The first synthesis of mono-substituted cationic cobaltocenium monomers via nucleophilic addition reaction; (2) robust phase-transfer anion-exchange method for making cationic cobaltocenium-containing polymers; (3) a templating strategy to the preparation of magnetic materials from cobaltocenium polymers; (4) an unexpected discovery that cationic cobaltocenium moieties can form unique ion-pairs with anionic β-lactam antibiotics, and exhibit superior bacteria-killing efficiency. In addition, we also develop the synthesis of ruthenocene-containing monomers and the first controlled/living polymerization techniques. We report the first chemoselective, high yield synthesis of cationic rhodocenium derivatives and monomers as well as the preparation of the first rhodocenium-containing metallopolymers by controlled polymerizations.

 

Broader Impact:

This project has significantly advanced our knowledge on cationic metallocene chemistry and preparation and utilities of their polymers. We have published over 18 papers and 1 patent application, delivered about 10 conference presentations and 20 seminars. This project has provided research opportunities to four graduate students and two postdoctoral scholars. Two graduate students have successfully obtain doctoral degrees. Four undergraduate students have been trained. We have trained over 20 high school students under our signature Project Seed Summer Program, involving more than twenty graduate students and 10 faculty including those from HBCUs. The PI has recently won the highest award for mentoring undergraduate students at the University of South Carolina: Distinguished Undergraduate Research Mentor Award. This award is a result of our efforts for mentoring 17 undergraduate students over the last six years.


Last Modified: 08/08/2015
Modified by: Chuanbing Tang
